domains.name: Discovery
domains.description: Activities and artifacts used to understand the problem, users, market context, existing alternatives, and the opportunity before defining strategic product commitments.

terms.name: Problem Statement
terms.definition: A structured articulation of the negative current state affecting Target Users that the Product is intended to change.
terms.description: Captures what is wrong today, who is impacted, and why it matters, creating a stable reference point for all later decisions and preventing solution drift.

terms.name: Target Users
terms.definition: Explicitly defined user groups whose needs, behaviors, and constraints are directly addressed by the Product.
terms.description: Defines which user groups are in scope for research and decision-making, guiding prioritization and preventing conflicting audience assumptions.

terms.name: Pain Points
terms.definition: Explicit difficulties, frustrations, or unmet needs experienced by Target Users in the current state.
terms.description: Lists concrete user problems and unmet needs to validate the necessity of a solution and to anchor opportunity exploration in real user evidence.

terms.name: Context and Constraints
terms.definition: Environmental, regulatory, operational, or situational conditions that define feasibility boundaries for the Product.
terms.description: Defines limiting conditions and external factors that shape what is possible, including rules, environments, dependencies, and operational realities.

terms.name: Market Landscape
terms.definition: An overview of market segments, trends, dynamics, and forces relevant to the Product context.
terms.description: Summarizes how the market is structured and changing, including segments and trends, to ground opportunity identification in external reality.

terms.name: Competitors
terms.definition: A structured list of existing alternatives, solutions, or providers addressing similar user needs in the same market.
terms.description: Catalogs relevant alternatives to ensure coverage of the real competitive set and to avoid false differentiation assumptions.

terms.name: Competitor Capability
terms.definition: A summary of competitor offerings expressed as capabilities, strengths, weaknesses, and differentiators.
terms.description: Analyzes what alternatives actually provide, highlighting patterns, strengths, weaknesses, and gaps that affect competitive viability.

terms.name: Market Opportunities
terms.definition: Specific gaps, needs, or trends in the market environment that can be leveraged to create value.
terms.description: Identifies where the market environment enables new value creation, driven by unmet demand, trends, structural inefficiencies, or emerging conditions.

terms.name: Opportunities
terms.definition: Clear areas where existing solutions fail to address user needs or where improvement can create meaningful value.
terms.description: Synthesizes where alternatives underperform against user needs, producing concrete openings grounded in user evidence and market context.

terms.name: Value Drivers
terms.definition: Specific sources of user or business value the Product can generate (e.g., convenience, cost savings, trust, speed, accuracy).
terms.description: Lists the main levers that create value, enabling prioritization and later translation into requirements, experience decisions, and success measurement.

terms.name: Customer Value
terms.definition: The concrete benefit delivered to users that explains why they would choose the Product.
terms.description: Describes the user benefit in practical terms, clarifying what improves for users and why adoption is rational compared to current alternatives.

terms.name: Market Fit
terms.definition: An early qualitative assessment of how well the proposed Product aligns with Target Users’ needs and behavior in the market context.
terms.description: Assesses whether the proposed direction is likely to be adopted and sustained, considering user behavior patterns and market realities.

terms.name: Feasibility Considerations
terms.definition: High-level indicators of viability across technical, operational, commercial, or regulatory dimensions.
terms.description: Evaluates whether the opportunity can realistically be executed within constraints, highlighting major risks, unknowns, and boundary conditions.
